metadata.title: Cu complex grafted on the porous materials: synthesis, characterization and comparison of their antibacterial activity with nano-Cu/NaY zeolite

sections.text:
Vol.:(0123456789)
Keywords Alkylaminopyridine/Cu complex · Porous materials · Nano-copper · Antibacterial agent · Release of nanoparticles

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
There are some microorganisms which make affliction for people, animals and planet safety, threatening their lives. Then, some researchers have investigated about new antibacterial agents and found safe and cost-effective materials for elimination and control of microorganism pollution on water and wastewater, pathogen and food processing environment [1]. Several studies showed that the metal nanoparticles (NPs) such as silver (Ag), copper (Cu) and zinc (Zn) which have been introduced to solid substrates, have antimicrobial properties and copper is a favorable candidate for bioactivity [2]. Therefore, extensive use of NPs in many areas such as
biology, medical and commercial products leads to leakage and accumulation of NPs in the environment [3, 4]. But recently, literature review shows release of many nanoparticles which are used in industry and household, which have a negative effect on the organisms and the environment [5]. For example, there are many microbes which have benefits for environment and ecosystem, because they play an important role in nitrogen fixation for plant growth, bioremediation and element cycling and NPs can be attached to them. Then, one of the most serious threats to beneficial microbes in ecosystems is the release of NPs into the environment [6]. To overcome this problem, using of different metal complexes has been developed. Unfortunately, the condition for preparation of these metal complexes is very difficult and some of them increased the resistance of bacteria and also show side effects for normal cells [7, 8].
Copper is one of the most important elements in biological systems. Also, Cu complexes with N, S, O donor groups such as Schiff base, dicarboxylate, amide-based and thiosemicarbazone ligands [9–11] not only have been gotten attention for catalytic reactions in industry but also

have remarkable antineoplastic, antifungal, antibacterial and antitumor activities [12, 13]. Literature review shows that the copper(II) complexes with N-heterocyclic ligands have inhibitory effects on the bacterial growth, offering a lower risk to biological use [13].
Hence, introducing antimicrobial complexes agent on the surface of inorganic materials like nanoparticles, porous materials and inorganic polymers has important advantages such as chemical and mechanical stability, thermal resistance, user’s safety and significantly longer duration of action [1, 14, 15]. According to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), microporous and mesoporous materials are defined as a porous material with pore diameters lower than 2 nm and between 2 and 50 nm, respectively [16, 17]. Various natural and synthetic porous materials such as MCM-41, SBA-15 and zeolite with high surface area, chemical inertness, high resistance and suitable channels have good ability to be functionalized with transition metal complexes. Covalent grafting of the metal complexes onto porous materials makes an easy separation of the solid antibacterial agent by simple filtration, and these materials can be reused multiple times without significant loss in their activity, alongside decreasing the cost [18].
The main goal of this work is to overcome the leakage of nanoparticles in the environment and decrease the side effects of antibacterial agents. In this effort, in the first step 2-aminopyridine/Cu complex with a N-donor ligand immobilized on the porous material (HY and MCM-41) with a simple and low-cost method. The modified porous materials characterized by SEM, EDX chemical analysis, DRS, FT-IR, XRD and TGA and insoluble antibacterial activity of these compounds were investigated in vitro against representative pathogens E. coli (ATCC 35218) and P. aeruginosa (ATCC 27853) as Gram-negative bacteria and S. aureus (ATCC 6538) and B. subtilis (ATCC 6633) as Gram-positive bacteria via utilizing the agar disk diffusion method under aerobic conditions. Also, the antibacterial activity of these materials is compared with NaY zeolite/nano-Cu composite materials. The performance of the modified porous materials as solid antibacterial agents is investigated for many applications such as water treatment.

sections.heading: Preparation of HY Zeolite and MCM‑41
sections.text: HY zeolite and MCM-41 were synthesized based on the other works, and the characterization method shows a highly ordered hexagonal siliceous for MCM-41 and high crystallinity for HY zeolite that is prepared [18, 19].

sections.heading: Preparation of P@ Pr‑Py/Cu (P= porous materials:
HY Zeolite and MCM‑41)
sections.text:
In the first step, 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (3-ClPTMS, 1 mmol) was reacted with 2-aminopyridine (1.2 mmol) at 90 °C for 30 h in 5 mL dry toluene under nitrogen atmosphere. The resulting material (PTMS-Py) was reacted with 1 g of P (HY zeolite or MCM-41) in 10 mL refluxing toluene
(dry) for 24 h under nitrogen atmosphere. Finally, the solid product was filtered, washed by chloroform, ethanol and water, respectively, and dried at 100 °C for 24 h [20]. In the second step, 10 mL dry toluene was added to 0.5 g P@Pr-Py and homogenized by ultrasonic for 30 min. Then, 0.05 g of CuCl2 was added to it and refluxed at 100 °C for 24 h under nitrogen atmosphere. The product was filtered and washed with different solvents (chloroform, ethanol and water) and dried [21]. Then, the P@Pr-Py/Cu was characterized by FT-IR, XRD, SEM, TGA and DRS techniques.

sections.heading: Preparation of NaY/Nano‑Cu
sections.text: To incorporate nano-Cu onto the zeolite, in the first step, 3 g of NaY zeolite was added to 100 ml Cu2+ solution (CuCl2 .2H2O, 0.08 M) and stirred for 48 h at room temperature. The resulted solid was filtered and, after washing with deionized water (three times), dried at 120 °C for 3 h. Then, it was added to NaBH4 solution (100 ml, 0.024 M) as a reduction agent and stirred for 1 h at room temperature [22, 23]. The product (NaY/nano-Cu) was filtered and washed with water, dried and characterized by different analysis techniques.

sections.heading: Antibacterial test
sections.text:
The antibacterial activity of the pure porous materials and prepared Z-HY@Pr-Py, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and NaY/nanoCu was investigated against two Gram-positive bacteria B. subtilis (ATCC 6538) and S. aureus (ATCC 6633) and two Gram-negative species E. coli (ATCC8739) and P.
1 3
aeruginosa (ATCC27853) according to the standard Hwang and Ma paper disc diffusion method [24]. In the first step, a disc of Z-HY@Pr-Py, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and NaY/nano-Cu of 3 mm diameter from 0.04 mg of the above composites was prepared and then was exposed to the Mueller-Hinton broth (Merck, Germany) which inoculated with 0.5 McFarland suspension of test bacteria. Finally, the diameters of the inhibition zones which formed around each disk were determined and presented in mm. The disk of antibacterial reagents was separately washed with suspension and maintained at 37 °C to consider the reusability of antibacterial agents at different times (8 and 24 h).

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text: In the first step, Z-HY@Pr-Py, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and NaY/ nano-Cu were prepared and characterized by different methods which are considered as follows:

sections.heading: FT‑IR spectra
sections.text:
FT-IR spectra of pure NaY and HY zeolite, Z-HY@Pr-Py, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and NaY/nano-Cu are presented in Table 1. The FT-IR spectra of all samples show an intense band at about ca. 1015–1049 cm−1 attributed to the asymmetric stretching of Al–O–Si bonds in the zeolite. The
1 3
symmetric stretching and bending frequency bands of Al–O–Si framework of zeolite appeared at 740–751 and 436–459 cm−1, respectively [25].
The FT-IR spectrum of HY zeolite after functionalizing with pyridine moiety shows the C–H and N–H vibration bands in the 2900–3500 cm−1 and 1500–1650 cm−1 region, and also a band in 1400 cm−1 could be regarded as the c stretching frequency [26, 27]. These bands are clearly absent in the NaY and HY zeolite spectra that confirm the successful attachment of organic fragments to the zeolite matrix. After anchoring Cu to amino-functionalized HY zeolite, a peak at around 790 cm−1 appeared that can be assigned to Cu–N bond and the band related to C–N bond shifted to lower frequency (about 1330 cm−1) which confirms the interaction between amine groups and copper ion [27]. In the case of NaY/nano-Cu after introducing Cu to zeolite, a peak at about 865 cm−1 related to Cu–O bond appeared [28]. The FT-IR spectra of MCM-41, MCM-41@Pr-Py and MCM-41@ Pr-Py/Cu are shown in Fig. 1. In all samples, the related symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of Si–O–Si bonds appeared at about 800 and 1100 cm−1, respectively. After functionalization with amine, a peak appeared at about 2930–3450 cm−1 attributed to N–H and C–H bonds. Also, with introducing copper to MCM-41@ Pr-Py, the peak at 1420 cm−1 related to C–N bond shifted to lower frequency and also a peak at about 700 cm−1 confirmed interaction between Cu–N.

sections.heading: The powder X‑ray diffraction study
sections.text:
The XRD patterns for HY zeolite, Z-HY@Pr-Py, Z-HY@ Pr-Py/Cu and also for NaY/nano-Cu and NaY zeolite are
shown in Fig. 2A (a–c) and B (a–c), respectively. It has been observed that the zeolite crystallites after anchoring the copper complex or after introducing nano-copper are almost same as the parent HY and NaY zeolite [29], due to fine distribution of materials in the zeolite lattice. X-ray diffraction pattern of Z-HY@Pr-Py is shown in Fig. 2A (a). Some diffraction peaks such as 2θ = 12.49°, 17.54°, 21.58°, 22.87°, 26.70°, 28.44°, 33.21°, 36.56°, 50.80°, 53.02°, 59.13°, 55.21° can be indexed as the HY zeolite [29].
The peak from nano-Cu introduced to the zeolite structure (Fig. 2B (b)) can clearly be seen at 2θ = 5.25 and 35.8 that provides additional hint for binding of nano-Cu on the surface of NaY zeolite [30, 31].
In the powder X-ray diffraction analysis for calcinated MCM-41, amino-functionalized MCM-41 (MCM-41@ Pr-Py) and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu, similar diffraction patterns appeared (Fig. 3a–c). Three strong diffractions for (100), (110) and (200) planes and a weak one for the (210) plane are reflections of 2D-hexagonal mesophase in the parent MCM-41, indicating the formation of a highly ordered mesophase [32]. X-ray diffraction pattern of MCM-41@ Pr-Py is shown in Fig. 3b. Some diffraction peaks such as 2θ = 1.33°, 1.8°, 3.9° and 4.4° can be indexed as the MCM41 [32]. An overall decrease in the intensity of the peaks is observed after functionalization that indicated considerable distortion occurs on the channels of the mesoporous materials which may due to a contraction of the pore volume in the grafted materials [33, 34], because of the immobilization of the bulky complexes with the silane linker on the surface and channels of MCM-41 (Fig. 3c). This is attributed to the loss of crystallinity, the lowering of local order and variations in the wall thickness [35].

sections.heading: The SEM, EDAX and elemental analysis
sections.text:
Figure 4a–c shows the FESEM micrographs of Z-HY@ Pr-Py/Cu, NaY/nano-Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu samples with a wide range of shapes and sizes of particles. The images of Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and NaY/nano-Cu indicated the presence of well-defined zeolite crystal with diameters in the range of 11–21 nm and 13–17 nm, respectively (Fig. 3a–b), which decreased with respect to pure NaY. The FESEM image of MCM-41@ Pr-Py/Cu shows high dispersion of copper and good crystallinity with size of about 13–19 nm (Fig. 4c). Also, based on other works, in the all samples presence the nanoparticles of copper create some changing in the surface of poros material (yellow label in Fig. 4a–c) can be due to the functionalization process and introducing nano copper on the surface of zeolite [36].
Furthermore, the EDX spectrum of Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu, NaY/nano-Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu samples revealed the presence of Cu; the peaks corresponding to Si, Al and O with Si/Al ratio of about 3.0 were contributed to the presence
1 3
1 3
of Y zeolite in the modified form (Fig. 4d, e); and also Si and O confirmed the presence of MCM-41 support (Fig. 4f). Also, the C/N ratio of about 3 in the Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu confirmed the presence of amine in the porous material after functionalization [18]. The elemental analyses of Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu show the presence of Cu % 1.32 and % 1.59, respectively (Table 2). Figure 5a, b for Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu, respectively, shows that the C, N and Cu were dispersed
uniformly over the porous support. But in the case of NaY/ nano-Cu sample (Fig. 5c), copper dispersed with higher concentration in the surface of porous materials was confirmed by the percent of Cu (%1.72) in the EDX analysis. These results may be due to trap of some alkylaminopyridine/Cu complex in the pores of zeolite and MCM-41.

sections.heading: DRS absorption
sections.text: The diffuse reflectance spectroscopy diagrams for NaY/ nano-Cu, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu are presented in Fig. 6a–c. In the case of NaY/nano-Cu (Fig. 6a), UV–Vis electronic spectra show two broad bands at about ~216 and ~247 nm related to n→n* of zeolite. UV–Vis/ DRS spectra of the amino-functionalized samples (Fig. 6b, c) show a typical absorption at ~245 and ~360 nm related to n→π* and π→π* of ligand charge transfer bands [30, 37–41]. The d↔d transitions bond of Cu+2 indicated at 588, 606 and 560 nm for NaY/nano-Cu, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu, respectively, which this characteristic band has been assigned to square planar copper(II) configuration [42, 43].

sections.heading: Thermal analysis
sections.text:
Figure 8 shows the TGA plot under N2 flow for Z-HY@ Pr-Py/Cu, NaY/nano-Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu. In all the samples, the first weight loss was attributed to desorption of physical and chemical water molecules. These weight losses are about 7.70% between 30 and 190 °C for Z-HY@Pr-Py/ Cu (a), 7.62% at 30–180 °C for NaY/nano-Cu (b) and 6.51%
at 30–190 °C for MCM–41@Pr-Py/Cu (c), respectively. The second weight loss for NaY/nano-Cu of about 4.35% (190–600 °C) occurred due to changing and decomposition of zeolite structure [47]. In the case of Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu, in the second step, the organometallic complex fragmented with the weight loss of about 4.10% (190–350 °C) and 7.13% (190–450 °C), respectively, which accompanied with endothermic peaks in DTG. The third step with 3.06% weight loss (350–600 °C) is assigned to the changing structure in zeolite for Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu, and this step with 4.7% weight loss (450–600 °C) corresponds

sections.heading: Biological studies
sections.text:
The results of disc diffusion assay for pure porous materials Pr-Py/Cu, NaY/nano-Cu, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@ Pr-Py/Cu are presented in Table 4 and are compared with vancomycin and nalidixic acid. The results show that introducing nano-copper or functionalization of porous materials with metal complex affected the inhibition growth of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. It seems that when copper was introduced into porous material (nano- or complex form), the antibacterial activity of them increased. Literature survey shows that metallic ions can be released from the composite and adsorbed to the surface of bacteria
which has negative charges by electrostatic force, and then destroy the charge balance of bacteria and lead to serious deformation of cells until bacteria die by bacteriolysis [51]. Also, the higher activity of the metal complexes related to ligand alone may be due to the good interaction between metal ions and normal cell membrane. The metals usually coordinate with HO- or HS- and H2N-terminals from proteins in a variety of modes and play a vital crucial role in the conformation and function of biological macromolecules [52].
In the metal complexes, overlap of ligand and metal orbitals reduces the polarity of metal ions and causes both polar and nonpolar properties , in which these properties are suitable for permeation into cells and tissues (Scheme 1). Metal interaction with ligand increases the delocalization of π-electrons over the entire ligand structure and increases the penetration of the metal complexes into the lipid membranes [53, 54]. Also, literature review shows that the presence of some groups such as pyridine with π-electrons over the whole chelating ring favored the permeation of the complex through the lipid layer of the bacterial cell membranes

Although, the interaction of nanoparticles against various bacteria is not understood completely, literature review shows that metallic and ionic forms of copper produce hydroxyl radicals which are released and attached to the membrane of bacteria by electrostatic interaction and disrupt the integrity of the membrane and also damage essential proteins and DNA (Scheme 1). The lower agglomeration of copper creates higher available surface area for interaction with bacterial membranes, which leads to more antibacterial efficiency [58, 59].
The antibacterial activity of prepared samples and other reported works is compared in Table 5. The results show that Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu exhibit higher antibacterial activity with respect to others. It seems that square planar copper(II) configuration and N-donor groups and also the presence of aminopyridine groups with high delocalization of π-electrons affected the antibacterial activity [13]. Also, the connection of PR-Py/Cu to zeolite and MCM-41 with a lot of electron affinity groups as a result of oxygen atoms in the framework, increased the polarity of metal ions which increased interaction between copper and bacterial membranes.
To consider the reusability of prepared antibacterial agents, the NaY/nano-Cu, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM41@Pr-Py/Cu were used for three runs until 24 h (Fig. 9).
The Pr-Py/Cu after one time using was destroyed because it was solved in the solvent. It can be seen that the antibacterial activity of NaY/nano-Cu has been decreased after 24 h may be due to the Cu2+ ions releasing which decreases the intensity of the peak at 2θ = 5.25 and 35.8 in XRD pattern (Fig. 2B (c)), confirming this subject. Also, elemental mapping in Fig. 10a–f shows that there is no significant change in the percent of copper after treatment with bacteria for Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu and MCM-41@Pr-Py/Cu but in the case of NaY/nano-Cu, the percent of Cu decreased which confirms the leakage of Cu NPs to environment.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
The alkylaminopyridine/Cu complex grafted on MCM-41 and HY zeolite and nano-copper-incorporated NaY zeolite were prepared and characterized. All structures morphology has particle sizes smaller than 100 nm and has good crystallinity. The prepared hybrid nanomaterials have good antibacterial activity against B. subtilis, S. aureus, E. coli and P. aeruginosa. The results show that introducing nanocopper or anchoring of copper complex with square planar structure which was introduced to porous materials affected the inhibition of bacterial growth till 24 h without significant releasing of copper from organometallic-modified porous materials in comparison with nano-Cu/NaY zeolite. So, good antibacterial agents have been prepared with high stability which can be effective for long time.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, the copper complex is introduced to porous materials, MCM-41 and NaY zeolite, by two ways. In the first way, nano-copper was incorporated into NaY zeolite (NaY/nano-Cu), and in the second way, alkylaminopyridine/Cu complex grafted on MCM-41 and HY zeolite pores (Z-HY@Pr-Py, Z-HY@Pr-Py/Cu). The prepared composites have been characterized by several techniques: scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray analysis chemical analysis, diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. The results have been shown that the Cu complex and nano-copper ions were supported successfully on porous materials. The synthesized samples were investigated in vitro for antibacterial activity against Gram-positive (B. subtilis and S. aureus) and Gram-negative (E. coli and P. aeruginosa) bacteria and compared with standard drugs. The results show that introducing nano-copper or anchoring the Cu complex to porous materials has affected the inhibition of bacterial growth. Also, there is no significant releasing of copper ions from alkylaminopyridine/Cu complex which was grafted on porous materials in comparison with NaY/nano-Cu until 24 h.
